Comprehensive Overview of Agricultural S:
In a bid to bolster the agricultural sector, the Indian government has rolled out a series of innovative schemes aimed at market intervention and technological advancement. These initiatives are designed to protect farmers from financial distress and ensure fair pricing for their produce, especially during periods of bumper crops when market prices plummet below production costs. The Market Intervention Scheme and Price Support Scheme (MIS-PSS) are pivotal in this regard. While the Price Support Scheme focuses on pulses, oilseeds, and copra, the Market Intervention Scheme extends its coverage to perishable agricultural and horticultural commodities not included in the PSS. These efforts are crucial in stabilizing farmers' incomes and safeguarding their livelihoods.

## Technological Integration in Agriculture

Beyond market support, the government is keen on integrating technology into agriculture. A notable initiative is the Namo Drone Didi scheme, which empowers Women Self Help Groups (SHGs) by providing drones for agricultural purposes, such as applying fertilizers and pesticides. This scheme, with a substantial financial outlay, offers an 80% subsidy on drone costs, encouraging SHGs to adopt sustainable business practices and generate additional income. Furthermore, it facilitates loans under the National Agriculture Infra Financing Facility, with interest subvention to alleviate financial burdens on SHGs.

## Infrastructure and Sustainable Practices

Several other schemes are focused on enhancing agricultural infrastructure and promoting sustainable practices. The Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojana (RKVY) supports state-specific projects to improve pre and post-harvest infrastructure. The Soil Health Card scheme provides farmers with essential soil nutrient information, optimizing crop production. The Rainfed Area Development (RAD) program promotes integrated farming systems to maximize farm returns and mitigate climate impacts. Initiatives like the Per Drop More Crop (PDMC) and the Micro Irrigation Fund (MIF) aim to improve water use efficiency through micro-irrigation technologies. Additionally, the Paramparagat Krishi Vikas Yojana (PKVY) encourages organic farming practices, while the Sub-Mission on Agriculture Mechanization (SMAM) enhances farm mechanization, including the promotion of drone technology. These comprehensive efforts underscore the government's commitment to advancing agricultural productivity, sustainability, and farmer welfare in India.
Comprehensive Initiatives for Agricultur:
Launched in April 2014, the Sub-Mission on Agricultural Mechanization (SMAM) aims to enhance agricultural mechanization across India, particularly targeting small and marginal farmers and regions with low farm power availability. This initiative promotes the establishment of Custom Hiring Centres to address challenges posed by small landholdings and high equipment costs. SMAM also focuses on creating hubs for high-tech, high-value farm equipment, conducting awareness programs, and building capacity. It ensures performance testing and certification at designated centers nationwide. Since its inception, over Rs 6,748.78 crore has been allocated to state governments, resulting in the distribution of more than 15,75,719 pieces of agricultural machinery and equipment, including tractors and power tillers. The initiative has successfully established 23,472 custom hiring centers, 504 hi-tech hubs, and 20,597 farm machinery banks.

## Crop Residue Management

The Crop Residue Management (CRM) initiative, which began in 2018-19, aims to curb air pollution and preserve soil nutrients by discouraging the burning of crop residue in Punjab, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh, and Delhi. CRM promotes in-situ management of crop residue and plans to establish Farm Machinery Banks for custom hiring of relevant machinery. The initiative emphasizes raising awareness through demonstrations, capacity building, and tailored communication strategies. Over Rs 3333.17 crore has been disbursed under CRM, facilitating the distribution of more than 2,95,845 CRM machinery. CRM has now been integrated into the SMAM, further strengthening its impact.

## Other Missions and Initiatives

Several other missions and initiatives have been launched to support various aspects of agriculture in India. The National Food Security Mission (NFSM) focuses on increasing the production of rice, wheat, pulses, and cereals sustainably, while the Sub-Mission on Seed and Planting Material (SMSP) aims to enhance seed quality and establish seed banks. The National Mission on Edible Oils (NMEO)-Oil Palm targets self-reliance in edible oils, and the Mission for Integrated Development of Horticulture (MIDH) promotes holistic growth in the horticulture sector. The National Bamboo Mission (NBM) focuses on developing the bamboo sector's value chain, and the Integrated Scheme for Agriculture Marketing (ISAM) supports market structure creation and access to market information. Additionally, the Mission Organic Value Chain Development for the North Eastern Region and the Sub-Mission on Agriculture Extension (SMAE) aim to develop organic production clusters and transform the extension system to be farmer-driven, respectively. Lastly, the Digital Agriculture initiative seeks to enhance the National e-Governance Plan in Agriculture by establishing a digital public infrastructure to provide inclusive and farmer-centric solutions.
Enhancing Agriculture through Digital In:
The Indian government is making strides in modernizing agriculture through digital means. A key initiative in this regard is the advancement of the National e-Governance Plan in Agriculture (NeGPA) by developing a digital public infrastructure for agriculture. This initiative is designed to be an open-source, open-standard, and interoperable public resource, serving as a foundation for inclusive and farmer-centric solutions. The primary goal is to provide farmers with access to essential information services that can aid in crop planning and health, ensure better availability of farm inputs, and offer credit and insurance options. Additionally, the scheme aims to assist with crop estimation, provide market intelligence, and support the growth of the Agri Tech industry and start-ups.

The architecture of this digital infrastructure, known as AgriStack, is built on several foundational layers. These include core registries and base databases, a Farmers Database that links farmers' IDs with land records, and geo-referencing of plots. It also encompasses crop surveys and planning, soil mapping and fertility assessments, and a Unified Farmers Service Interface that can be utilized by state and private players. Furthermore, the infrastructure facilitates data exchange, which is crucial for the seamless operation of these services.

Overall, the scheme represents a significant step towards modernizing agriculture through digital means. By leveraging technology, it aims to empower farmers with the tools and information they need to make informed decisions, improve productivity, and enhance their livelihoods. The initiative also seeks to foster innovation and entrepreneurship within the agricultural sector, ultimately contributing to the broader goal of sustainable agricultural development.
Comprehensive Overview of Central Govern:
Central Government Schemes are initiatives implemented by a country's central government to address specific issues, provide benefits, or promote growth in various sectors of the economy or society. In India, these schemes are particularly crucial for the agricultural sector, aiming to improve infrastructure, enhance rural development, promote job creation, and provide financial support to farmers. The necessity of these schemes lies in their ability to offer a sustainable livelihood to citizens, especially those in lower-income groups, by providing capital, guidance, and professional assistance for farming activities. They also offer a safe way to access credit, reduce agricultural risks through crop insurance, and provide farm implements and equipment at subsidized rates, facilitating modern farming practices.

## Key Central Government Schemes

Among the top central government agriculture schemes in India are the Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi (PM-KISAN), Pradhan Mantri Kisan Maandhan Yojana (PM-KMY), and Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY). PM-KISAN provides income support to small and marginal farmers by transferring INR 6000 annually in three installments. PM-KMY is a pension scheme ensuring a continual income source for farmers post-retirement, offering a monthly pension of Rs. 3,000. PMFBY addresses crop loss issues by providing financial assistance and risk reduction in the event of crop damage due to natural disasters, pests, or diseases, making insurance more affordable and accessible to farmers.

Other notable schemes include the Modified Interest Subvention Scheme (MISS), which offers short-term loans at reduced interest rates to prevent farmer suicides due to credit scarcity. The Agriculture Infrastructure Fund (AIF) provides medium to long-term loans for post-harvest management and infrastructure development. The Formation & Promotion of new 10,000 FPOs scheme supports Farmer Producer Organizations with financial support and credit facilities. Lastly, the National Beekeeping and Honey Mission (NBHM) aims to promote beekeeping and honey production, contributing to agricultural diversification and income generation for farmers. These schemes collectively aim to enhance the agricultural sector's stability, support farmers' financial well-being, and promote sustainable agricultural practices in India.
